Name: Bug ID
Description: Identifier of the bug within the issue tracking system.

Name: Bug severity
Description: Severity of the bug, e.g., major or minor

Name: Bug labels
Description: Additional labels of the bug, e.g., components or similar.

Name: # Bug discussants
Description: Number of people involved in the reporting and discussion of the bug

Name: Aspects of the Bug discussion
Description: Aspects that were discussed, e.g., how to fix the bug or related features. Stored as a list as discussion may have multiple aspects. (description of the bugs, title and comments)

Name: Type of Bug
Description: Type of bug that was introduced following the taxonomy proposed by Catolino et al. [3] as one of the following: configuration issue, network issue, database-related issue, GUI-related issue, performance issue, permission/deprecation issue, security issue, program anomaly issue, and test code-related issue.

Name: Bug has duplicate
Description: Whether the bug has any duplicate within the project.

Name: Bug reopened
Description: Yes, in case the bug was reopened at some point on time.. No, in the other case.

Name: Introducing issues IDs
Description: Identifier of the issue as part of which the development happened that introduced the bug. All related variables are lists, as there might have been parallel development on multiple issues.

Name: Introducing issue types
Description: Type of the introducing issue, e.g., bug or improvement.

Name: Introducing issue severity
Description: Severity of the introducing issue

Name: Introducing issue labels
Description: Additional labels of the introducing issue.

Name: # Introducing issue discussants
Description: Number of people involved in the reporting and discussion of [per] issue

Name: Introducing issue discussant roles
Description: Whether the issue discussants were core developers, peripheral developers or not involved in the project before.

Name: Introducing issue reporter role
Description: Whether the highest-ranking issue reporter was a core developer, peripheral developer or not involved in the project before.

Name: Introducing issue assignee role
Description: Whether the highest-ranking issue assignee was a core developer, peripheral developer or not involved in the project before

Name: Introducing issue creator role
Description: Whether the highest-ranking issue creator was a core developer, peripheral developer or not involved in the project before.

Name: Aspects of introducing issue discussion
Description: Aspects that were discussed, e.g., discussion of solution variants. Stored as a list as a discussion may have multiple aspects

Name: # Introducing issue commits
Description: Number of commits in which the introducing issue was addressed.

Name: Introducing issue has wiki/specification
Description: if the Introducing issue has a wiki or a specification. Which means that the introducing issue has a detailed description of the issue

Name: ML bug discussion IDs
Description: Identifier of emails related to the discussion of the bug (i.e. the bug fixing commit and the bug issue) on the Mailing List (ML).

Name: # ML bug discussants
Description: Number of people involved in the discussion of the bug on the ML.

Name: ML bug discussant roles
Description: Whether the discussants in the ML of the bug were core developers, peripheral developers or not involved in the project before.

Name: Aspects of ML bug discussion
Description: Aspects that were discussed in the ML of the bug.

Name: ML introducing change discussion IDs
Description: Identifier of emails related to the discussion of the introducing change (i.e. the introducing commit or the introducing issue).

Name: # ML introducing change discussants
Description: Number of people involved in the discussion of the introducing change on the ML.

Name: ML introducing change discussant roles
Description: Whether the discussants in the ML of the introducing change were core developers, peripheral developers or not involved in the project before.

Name: Aspects of ML introducing change discussion
Description: Aspects that were discussed in the ML of the introducing change.

Name: Identifier of related information in other media
Description: Identifier of all discussions about the bug that we could locate in other media of the project.

Name: Type of other media in which bug was discussed
Description: Types of other media that were used, e.g., developer blogs, forums, and chats

Name: # Discussants in other media
Description: Number of discussants involved in other media.

Name: Discussant roles in other media
Description: Whether the discussants involved in other media were core developers, peripheral developers or not involved in the project before.

Name: Aspects of discussions in other media
Description: Aspects that were discussed in other media

Name: Buggy files arepresent in the BIC?
Description: Are the buggy files, indicated by Gema Study, present in in BIC? . Yes, all; Yes, partially; NO

Name: CI build ID
Description: Identifier of a build in the continuous integration (CI) system.

Name: CI build status
Description: Status of the CI build.

Name: CI build status change
Description: Whether the status of the CI build is the same as for the previous commit

Name: Build tools
Description: Tooling used for building the software, e.g., Gradle or Maven. List in case multiple tools are used as part of a tool chain. Based on our discussion, building is the process of developing, not on only "putting everything in a package"

Name: Dependency resolution
Description: How external dependencies are resolved, e.g., to imported libraries. Possible values are remote repositories (e.g., maven central), project cache (i.e., a cache of dependencies that is maintained by the project), and mixed.

Name: Build practices
Description: The practices that are used as part of the build process as a list of nominal values. We pre-define a set of categories as part of this registration. This set will be inductively extended as part of the data collection, if required. The pre-defined categories are: usage of bug-finding static analysis tools (e.g., SpotBugs will be the tool in B1 for this practice), usage of style-checking static analysis tools (e.g., Checkstyle will be the tool in B1), execution of automated unit and integration tests, execution and reporting of automated system tests, execution and reporting of other automated tests (e.g., performance tests), measurement and reporting of code coverage, and generation of source code documentation

Name: Commit revision hash
Description: Revision hash of the bug-introducing change

Name: Commit type (current)
Description: How the commit was added to the main branch as one of the following: direct commit, merge of pull request, merge of textual diff provided, other.

Name: Commit types (children)
Description: How the child commits were added to the main branch between the following: direct commit, merge of pull request, merge of textual diff provided, other.

Name: Commit types (parents)
Description: How the parent commits were added to the main branch between the following: direct commit, merge of pull request, merge of textual diff provided, other.

Name: # Files changed
Description: Number of files that were changed.

Name: Commit file bugginess
Description: Percentage of changed files that were responsible for the bug introduction.

Name: Commit total line bugginess
Description: Percentage of code lines within the commit that are bug-introducing

Name: Commit file line bugginess
Description: Percentage of lines within the files that have bug-introducing changes

Name: Committer type
Description: Whether the developer was a core developer, peripheral developer, or first-time committer. Categories will be defined following Joblin et al..

Name: Multiple concerns
Description: Whether the commit addressed multiple concerns, e.g., because multiple intends are stated in the commit messages or there are changes beyond the indent based on the commit message.

Name: Commit type Swanson
Description: Commit type according to Swanson as perfective, corrective, adaptive. Encoded as a list, in case a commit tangles multiple concerns (e.g. a bug fix and a feature addition at the same time).

Name: Test changes
Description: Whether any automated tests were added or changed

Name: Bug-covering test changes
Description: Whether any tests covering the bug were added or changed. None, if there are no such changes; partial, if there are changes but not all introducing lines are covered; and covered, if all introducing lines are covered.

Name: Bug-covering changes prior or subsequent commit
Description: Same as bug-covering test changes, except that neighboring commits (parents and children) and other commits for introducing issues are considered as well.

Name: Test failures
Description: Whether there are any test failures reported

Name: Documentation changes
Description: Whether any documentation was changed.

Name: Bug affecting documentation
Description: Whether any documentation directly related to the lines in which the bug was introduced changed, e.g., the comment of a method with bug-introducing code or in-line comments between bug-introducing code lines.

Name: Refactorings
Description: Whether any refactorings were conducted as part of the bug-introducing change

Name: Bug-introducing refactorings
Description: Whether there are any refactorings within the bug-introducing code.

Name: Design changes
Description: Whether the change includes changes to the design (or architecture) of the software, e.g., by adding new classes or packages.

Name: Bug-introducing design changes
Description: Whether there are any design changes as part of the bug-introducing code

Name: Change of external dependencies
Description: Whether there are any changes to the external dependencies, e.g., updates, additions, or removal of external libraries.

Name: Bug-introducing dependency changes
Description: Whether there are any changes to the external dependencies that affect the bugintroducing code

Name: Code review IDs
Description: Identifier of the review within the code review tool.

Name: Review tool
Description: Tooling that was used to conduct the code review, e.g., Gerrit, GitHub pull request, or textual comments in the issue based on code provided within a branch or textual diff. One list of nominals for each system, as we may have multiple comments in multiple locations. [main â†’ code review of main branch]

Name: # Reviewers
Description: Number of developers that reviewed code.

Name: Reviewer types
Description: Whether the reviewers were core developers, peripheral developers, or not involved in the project before.

Name: # Review comments
Description: Number of comments left by reviewers.

Name: # Rounds of code review
Description: Rounds of subsequent code review. A new round starts when the author provIDes an update of the code and requests reviewers to reassess the code.

Name: Caused changes
Description: Whether the code review led to any changes in the code.

Name: Aspects of review comments
Description: Aspects discussed as part of the code review, e.g., current bugs, style changes, efficiency, or similar.

Name: Bug covering review comments
Description: True if the code review led to commennts in the buggy file

Name: Bug covering review changes
Description: True if the code review led to changes in the buggy file

Name: Review branch
Description: Type of the branch (main or secondary) on which the reviews were done.
